pullRequest.title: Cache refresh for container recreate with same id
pullRequest.bodyText:
This PR will fix the following issue:
Client create collection A, delete it, and then recreate with same Id(within a short time window), then when queryItems, will get the following exceptions:
{"Errors":["The requested resource is no longer available at the server."]}
"gatewayStatistics":{"sessionToken":null,"operationType":"Query","statusCode":410,"subStatusCode":1000,
The solution here is to catch the specific exception and then refresh the cache then retry

nodes.bodyText:
Not sure I picked up the best places to wire up the invalid partitionExceptionRetryPolicy. Several thoughts and questions:

Trying to put this logic as low as the query pipeline
Since for parallelQuery, each partition will have its own request, so at this point, there will be no request associate with this retry policy.
I see usually we define next policy, but in this case, I do not think we need to define any. does it make sense?
For default document context, it already wired up InvalidPartitionExecptionRetry, but I do not see harm to wire it again here
Currently, for pipelinedDocumentQuery, we have retry policy for each partition. For example throttleRetryPolicy,  does it mean each partition will retry n times? should this number be shared across all the partitions?

this test group will run against prod endpoint.
Creating container/deleting container is expensive against prod. We usually use emulator for such tests.
Please see this test class: CollectionCrudTest.java (it uses emulator for test group).
Could you please create a new Java Test class (ContainerCreateDeleteWithSameNameTest.java) similar to CollectionCrudTest and move this test method there?
we need to test more scenarios (point read, write, query, change feed) on container create delete so it is better if we have a separate test class for that.
WOW such a compact code. Equivalent .NET one is reasonably verbose.
it might be worth having this as a constant with a quick explanation for why it is needed (emulator's deletes are not instantaneous).
